Medical researchers analyze how different dosages of a drug affect the duration of relief from allergic symptoms. They want to develop a statistical model to predict the time of relief (in days) based on the dosage of a new drug. Identify the predictor variable and the response variable.
answer1: The predictor variable is a dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the time of relief.
answer2: The predictor variable is the time of relief; the response variable is the dosage of the new drug.
answer3: The predictor variable is the mean of time of relief; the response variable is the mean of dosage of the new drug.
answer4: The predictor variable is the mean of dosage of a new drug; the response variable is the mean of time of relief.

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & - & 4z & = & 2 \\ 
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\ 
x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $(5,3,3)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(10,5,6)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The system has $(\frac{5}{3}z,1+\frac{2}{3}z,z)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
How many solutions does the following linear system have?
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & 3y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & y & + & 4z & = & -2 \\
x & - & 6y & + & 13z & = & -7
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter.
answer4: The system has a unique solution.

question:
The Cost-Less Corp. supplies its four retail outlets from its three plants. The shipping cost per unit from each plant $(i)$ to each retail outlet $j$ ($K$, $L$, $M$ and $N$) is given below:

\[
\begin{array}{lc|cccc|}
& & \text{K} & \text{L} & \text{M} & \text{N}\\
\hline
& \text{A} & 2 & 4 & 5 & 1 \\
\text{Plant} & \text{B} & 3 & 4 & 5 & 7 \\
& \text{C} & 4 & 5 & 7 & 4 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]	

Plants $A$, $B$ and $C$ make $80$, $140$ and $130$ units per month, respectively. Retail outlets $K$, $L$, $M$ and $N$ need to receive $80$, $30$, $90$ and $120$ units per month, respectively. Suppose that each unit maintained at plants $A$, $B$ and $C$ has a penalty cost (in monetary units) of $0.5$, $1$ and $1$, respectively. Use the transportation simplex method to determine the best plan for how many units to send from each plant to the retail outlets each month, minimizing the total shipping cost. Use the minimum cost rule to obtain an initial basic feasible solution.

answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

question:
The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.
	
In this situation, what are the decision variables to formalize the Linear Programming (LP) model that allows planning the company's activity?
answer1: $x_{i}$ the number of units of product $i$ produced ($i=1$, for product $A$ and $i=2$, for product $B$).
answer2: $x$ the number of units of product $1$ and $2$ produced.
answer3: $x_{1}$ is the number of units of product $1$ produced.
answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of units of product $2$ produced.

question:

6x & - & 11y & + & 2z & - & 9t & = & 2 \\
2x & + & y & - & 2z & - & t & = & 1 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & - & 2t & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(0,\,1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(1+z,\,0,\,z,\,-z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(1-y,\,y,\,2+y,\,-y\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the general solution for the differential equation system

$\begin{cases}
x'(t)=2x+y \\
y'(t)=x+3y-z \\
z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

question:
Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
x & + & y & - & z & + & w & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x+y,\,x-y-1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

3x & - & y & - & 3z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3

answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{22w+7}{15},\,\frac{-7w-7}{10},\,\frac{11w+11}{30}\bigg)$ for every $w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,6,\,-2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(3w,\,w-1,\,2w,\,w\right)$ as solution for every $w\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer1: The problem has the minimizer $\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right),$ the minimum value of the function being $-\frac{1}{2}.$
answer2: There are two minimizers $\left(\frac{1}{4}, \frac{3}{4}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{4},\frac{1}{4}\right)$ where the minimum value of the function is $-\frac{3}{8}.$
answer3: There are two maximizers $\left(\frac{2}{5}, \frac{3}{5}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)$ where the maximum value of the function is $-\frac{12}{25}.$

For each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, describe the solutions of the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:

answer4: The system has $\left(-2z+y,y,z\right)$ as solution for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: Indicate which of the following set of vectors is a spanning set of $\mathbb{R}^2$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & + & 2z & = & a \\
x & + & 2y & + & z & = & b \\
x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
4x & + & 3y & + & 4z & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has solutions if and only if $a=-2$ and $b=5$. 
In this case, there is an infinite number of solution, which are of the form $\left(x,\,4,\,-3-x\right)$ for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer2:
The system has solutions if and only if $a \neq \frac{7}{4}$ and $b \neq \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the solutions are of the form $\left(\frac{3}{4}a-z,\,\frac{1}{4}b,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has solutions if and only if $a = \frac{7}{4}$ and $b = \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the unique solution is $\left(\frac{3}{4},\,\frac{1}{4},\,0\right)$.

The Omega Manufacturing Company has discontinued the production of a certain unprofitable product line. This act created considerable excess production capacity. Management is considering devoting this excess capacity to one or more of three products; call them products 1, 2, and 3. The available capacity on the machines that might limit output is summarized in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|c|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Machine Type} & \text{Available Time (machine hours per week)} \\
	\hline
	\text{Milling machine} & 500 \\
	\text{Lathe} & 350 \\
	\text{Grinder} & 150 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}\]
		
The number of machine hours required for each unit for a given product is the following:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Machine Type} & \text{Product 1} & \text{Product 2} & \text{Product 3} \\
	\hline
	\text{Milling machine} & 9 & 3 & 5 \\
	\text{Lathe} & 5 & 4 & 0 \\
	\text{Grinder} & 3 & 0 & 2 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}\]
	
	The sales department indicates that the sales potential for products 1 and 2 exceeds the maximum production rate and the sales potential for product 3 is 20 units per week. The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning of the company's activity?
answer1:
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
	        & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			& x_{2}\leq 60\\
			&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
			    & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\leq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
    			& 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\geq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]

$$ \begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
x & 0 & 4 & 8 & 12 & 16 & 20 \\ 
\hline
f(x) & 30 & 20 & 10 & 20 & 15 & 8 \\
\hline
\end{array}$$

Calculate, in the sense of minimum least squares method, the polynomial of degree $1$ that fits the data.

Let $z_1=\frac{1}{2}+\sqrt{3}i$. 
Find $\text{Im}\left(\left(\overline{z_1}\right)^2\right)$.

Find $\ell_1 = \lim\limits_{x \to 0}(\lim\limits_{y \to 0}f(x,y)),\, \ell_2=\lim\limits_{y \to 0}(\lim\limits_{x \to 0}f(x,y)),$ and $\ell = \lim\limits_{(x,y) \to (0,0)}f(x,y),$ where $$f(x,y)=\frac{x^2y^2}{x^2y^2+(x-y)^4}$$
and $(x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2 \setminus (0,0)$.
Consider in the three-dimensional cartesian system the plane of equation $\pi: 2x-3y+z-1=0$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(-1, -1, 0)$ and is normal to the vector $n=(-4, 6, -2)$.
answer2: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, 1, 0)$ and is parallel to the vector $n=(2, 3, 1)$.
answer3: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, 1, 1)$ and is normal to the vector $n=(2, -3, 1)$.
answer4: The plane $\pi$ contains the point $P=(1, -1, 0)$ and is parallel to the vector $n=(2, -3, 1)$.

ax+y\right) $. The value of $a\in \mathbb{R}$ that is a solution of equation $\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial x^{2}}=9\dfrac{\partial ^{2}f}{\partial y^{2}},\forall x,y\in \mathbb{R}$, is:

The staff of a seaport works 8 hours a day, two blocks of 4 hours, obligatorily separated by 1 hour to rest. Given the 24 hours a day, the company has to hire six shifts with a 4-hour interval start (e.g. the 1st shift starts at 0:00 a.m., the 2nd at 4 a.m., the 3rd at 8:00 a.m., ..., the 6th at 8:00 p.m.). Supposing that the number of workers required to the proper functioning of the port is indicated in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|l|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of workers} \\
	\hline
	\text{0:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 10 \\
	\text{8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 40\\
	\text{4:00 p.m. to 0:00 a.m.} & 20 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}
	\]

How does the linear programming model should be formalized to allow planning the proper functioning of the port, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of  workers in shift $i~(i = 1~to~6)$?
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}	
			\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 10\\
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 40\\
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 40\\
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 20\\
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 20\\
			& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~6\\
			\end{array}
			\]

Consider the linear applications 

$\begin{array}{cccc}
F: & \mathbb{R}^3 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y, z) & \longrightarrow & (y, x-z)
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{cccc}
G: & \mathbb{R}^2 & \rightarrow  & \mathbb{R}^2 \\
  & (x, y) & \longrightarrow & (x+y, x-2y)
\end{array}$

Choose the right answer:
answer1: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)$ does not exist
answer2: $(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$and $(G\circ F)$ does not exist
answer3: $(G\circ F)(x, y, z)=(F\circ G)(x, y, z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$
answer4: $(G\circ F)(y, x-z)=(x+y-z, -2x+y+2z)$ and $(F\circ G)(x, y)=(x+y, x-2y)$

\[
f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow\mathbb{R},\text{ }f(x,y)=x^{2}+y^{3}%
\].

The Omega Manufacturing Company has discontinued the production of a certain unprofitable product line. This act created considerable excess production capacity. Management is considering devoting this excess capacity to one or more of three products; call them products 1, 2, and 3. The available capacity on the machines that might limit output is summarized in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|c|c|}
			\hline
			\text{Machine Type} & \text{Available Time (machine hours per week)} \\
			\hline
			\text{Milling machine} & 500 \\
			\text{Lathe} & 350 \\
			\text{Grinder} & 150 \\
			\hline
			\end{array}\]
	
The number of machine hours required for each unit for a given product is the following:
	
		\[\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
			\hline
			\text{Machine Type} & \text{Product 1} & \text{Product 2} & \text{Product 3} \\
			\hline
			\text{Milling machine} & 9 & 3 & 5 \\
			\text{Lathe} & 5 & 4 & 0 \\
		\text{Grinder} & 3 & 0 & 2 \\
			\hline
		\end{array}\]
	
	The sales department indicates that the sales potential for products 1 and 2 exceeds the maximum production rate and the sales potential for product 3 is 20 units per week. The unit profit would be 50?, 20?, and 25? for products 1, 2, and 3, respectively. The objective is to determine how much of each product the company should produce to maximize the profit. Formulate a linear programming model for this problem, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of units of product $i~(i = 1~to~3)$ produced.
Select the linear transformation which is an isomorphism.
Express $z=\operatorname{e}^{i\frac{2\pi}{3}}$ in the form $z=a+bi$.

Consider the function $f(x,y)=\dfrac{x-y^{4}}{x^{3}-y^{4}}$, where $y^{4} \neq x^{3}$.

Study the limits
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]$, $\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]$ and $\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y).$
answer1:
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=\frac{1}{3}$, $\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=1$, but the limit
$\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y)$ does not exist.
answer2:
$\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=\lim\limits_{y\rightarrow 1}\Big [\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow 1}f(x,y)\Big]=1$, but the limit
$\lim\limits_{ (x,y)\rightarrow (1,1)}f(x,y)$ does not exist.

question: The Fire Safety Department conducted a study to determine the percentage of households in the country that have smoke detectors. $1000$ households were checked and $875$ of them had a detector. Identify the population of interest in this case.

Find the conditional extrema of the function $f(x,y)=x^2+y^2-x-y$ having the constraint $x+y=1.$
answer1: The problem has the minimizer $\left(\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right),$ the minimum value of the function being $-\frac{1}{2}.$
answer2: There are two minimizers $\left(\frac{1}{4}, \frac{3}{4}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{4},\frac{1}{4}\right)$ where the minimum value of the function is $-\frac{3}{8}.$
answer3: There are two maximizers $\left(\frac{2}{5}, \frac{3}{5}\right)$ and $\left(\frac{3}{5},\frac{2}{5}\right)$ where the maximum value of the function is $-\frac{12}{25}.$
answer4: The problem has no extrema corresponding to this constraint.

question:
Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &0 \\ 
&3x &- &y &- &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer3:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(3+z,2-2z,z),\, \forall z\in \mathbb{R}$$.
answer4:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameter:
$$(3+z+y,y,z),\, \forall y,z\in \mathbb{R}$$.

answer2: $A$ is an orthogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$ but $B$ isn't an orhtogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$
answer3: $A$ and $B$ are both orthogonal basis of of $\mathbb{R}^3$
answer4: $A$ and $B$ are both non-orthogonal basis of $\mathbb{R}^3$

answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{4}t-\frac{7}{12},\frac{3}{4}t-\frac{3}{4},t\bigg)$, for all $t\in\mathbb{R}$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system, given the values of the parameters $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x &- &4y &- &4z &= &\alpha \\ 
x &- &3y &- &z &= &\beta \\ 
2x &+ &4y &+ &z &= &\gamma
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{-\alpha+12\beta+8\gamma}{29},\,\frac{3\alpha-7\beta+5\gamma}{29},\,\frac{-10\alpha+4\beta-7\gamma}{29}\right)$.
answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.
answer3: The sistem has no solutions for every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$, the system has infinite solutions, which are $\left(\alpha-\beta+\gamma+z,\,1+z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:

$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & + & 2z & - & 3t & = & 1 \\ 
2x & + & y & - & 2z & - & t & = & 2 \\ 
x &- &3y &+ &z &- &2t &= &-1 \\
  &   &      &     &z &- &t &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(5,\,1,\,3,\,3\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(5+20y,\,y,\,-10-13y,\,8+15y\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(5,0,-10,8\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:

x & - & 2y & - & z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,0,\,1+y\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,\,0,\,0,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(0,\,y,\,0,\,z\right)$ as solutions for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

answer3: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was equal to $7 m/s$.
answer4: $50\%$ of the sampled observations had speed that was less than or equal to $10 m/s$.

answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
4x & + & y & - & 5z & - & 3w & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x-y,\,x+y+1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

Letting $j := e^{\frac{2i\pi}{3}}$, find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & - & z & = & 0 \\ 
x & + & jy & + & j^{2}z & = & a \\ 
 &  & j^{2}y & + & jz & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a+b\neq 0$. 

If $b=-a$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer2: The system has no solution for every value of $a$ and $b$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,0,0\right)$ as its unique solution if $a=b=0$, and for all other values of $a$ and $b$ the system has no solutions.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.

Throughout the week, a web store recorded the number of mobile phones sold per day:

 \hline
 \text{Weekday}&\text{I} &\text{II} & \text{III} &\text{IV}& \text{V}&\text{VI}&\text{VII} \\

\text{Number of sold phones}& 12& 8&12&4&8&11&12 \\ 
 \hline
\end{array}$

Find the mode of the number of sold phones.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 3y & + & 6z & = & a \\ 
3x & + & y & + & 3z & = & 1 \\ 
6x & + & 6y & + & z & = & 1 \\
7x & + & 9y & + & 7z & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions for $b\neq a+1$. 

If $b=a+1$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{37-14a}{100},\,\frac{3a-4}{20},\,\frac{1+3a}{25}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The system has no solution for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
If $b\neq a+1$, the system has no solutions. 

Otherwise, for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{3+3a-z}{2},\,\frac{2+a-2z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
If $b=a+1$ the system has no solution. 

Otherwise, for every $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{a+b+1}{20},\,\frac{-a-b+2}{3},\,\frac{2a+3b-4}{15}\right)$.

answer4: $x_{2}$ is the number of units of product $2$ produced.

iz &- &w &= &1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\bigg(\frac{1-i}{2},\frac{-1+i}{2}\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(z,-iz)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.

question:

$$\begin{cases}
(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
4x & + & y & - & 5z & - & 3w & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x-y,\,x+y+1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the general solution for the differential equation system

$\begin{cases}
x'(t)=2x+y \\
y'(t)=x+3y-z \\
z'(t)=-x+2y+3z
\end{cases}$
answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{t}(\cos (t)-3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{t}(3\cos (t)+\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+5C_{2}e^{t}\cos (t)+5C_{3}e^{t}\sin (t),
\end{cases}$
where $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3} \in \mathbb{R}$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 3y & + & 6z & = & a \\ 
3x & + & y & + & 3z & = & 1 \\ 
6x & + & 6y & + & z & = & 1 \\
7x & + & 9y & + & 7z & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions for $b\neq a+1$. 

If $b=a+1$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{37-14a}{100},\,\frac{3a-4}{20},\,\frac{1+3a}{25}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The system has no solution for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
If $b\neq a+1$, the system has no solutions. 

Otherwise, for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{3+3a-z}{2},\,\frac{2+a-2z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
If $b=a+1$ the system has no solution. 

Otherwise, for every $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{a+b+1}{20},\,\frac{-a-b+2}{3},\,\frac{2a+3b-4}{15}\right)$.

question: Consider the differentiable function $f:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, $f(x,y,z)=x^{2}yz-\cos \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}.$ Find $\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y},\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}.$
answer1:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer2:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=2xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer3:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz+yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z+xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xe^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y+xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xye^{yz}$
answer4:
$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}(x,y,z)=xyz-yz\sin \left( xyz\right) +e^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}(x,y,z)=x^{2}z-xz\sin \left( xyz\right) +xze^{yz}$

$\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial z}(x,y,z)=x^{2}y-xy\sin \left( xyz\right) +xyze^{yz}$

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & y & - & 3z & + & 2t & = & 1 \\
2x & - & y & - & z & + & t & = & 0 \\
x & + & y & + & z & - & t & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The solutions of the system are of the form $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},\frac{1}{4}t-\frac{7}{12},\frac{3}{4}t-\frac{3}{4},t\bigg)$, for all $t\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\bigg(-\frac{2}{3},-\frac{7}{12},-\frac{3}{4},0\bigg)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The solution of the system is the vector of coordinates $(2,-1,0,0)$.

question:

2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
4x & + & y & - & 5z & - & 3w & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x-y,\,x+y+1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

Letting $j := e^{\frac{2i\pi}{3}}$, find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & - & z & = & 0 \\ 
x & + & jy & + & j^{2}z & = & a \\ 
 &  & j^{2}y & + & jz & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a+b\neq 0$. 

If $b=-a$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer2: The system has no solution for every value of $a$ and $b$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,0,0\right)$ as its unique solution if $a=b=0$, and for all other values of $a$ and $b$ the system has no solutions.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.

$$\begin{cases}

x &  &  & + & z & = & c
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(a-b+2c,\,3a-2b+3c,\,-a+b-c\right)$.
answer3:
The system has no solution for $a\neq 0$. 
If $a=0$ and for every value of $b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(2c-b,\,3c-2b,\,b-c\right)$.
answer4: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has $\left(1,\,1,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.

question:
For each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, describe the solutions of the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

$f\left(  -\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},-\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},-\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3}\right)$ is the minimum.

answer2:

 $f\left(  \frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3},\frac{2\sqrt{6}}{3}\right)  \ $ is the minimum.

answer4:
$f(0,0,0)$ is the minimum.
$f(1,1,1)$ is the maximum.

Supposing that the number of workers required to the proper functioning of the port is indicated in the following table:
	
	\[\begin{array}{|l|c|}
	\hline
	\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of workers} \\
	\hline
	\text{0:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 10 \\
	\text{8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 40\\
	\text{4:00 p.m. to 0:00 a.m.} & 20 \\
	\hline
	\end{array}
	\]

How does the linear programming model should be formalized to allow planning the proper functioning of the port, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of  workers in shift $i~(i = 1~to~6)$?
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}	
			\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 10\\
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 40\\
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 40\\
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 20\\
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 20\\
			& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~6\\
			\end{array}
			\]

\partial y}\left( x,y\right) =2\left( f(x,y)+xy\right) $

answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:

answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:

Letting $j := e^{\frac{2i\pi}{3}}$, find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & - & y & - & z & = & 0 \\ 
x & + & jy & + & j^{2}z & = & a \\ 
 &  & j^{2}y & + & jz & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a+b\neq 0$. 

If $b=-a$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer2: The system has no solution for every value of $a$ and $b$.
answer3: The system has $\left(0,0,0\right)$ as its unique solution if $a=b=0$, and for all other values of $a$ and $b$ the system has no solutions.
answer4: For every $a,b\in\mathbb{C}$ the system has $\left(\frac{a+(1+2j)z}{1+j},\,\frac{a+jz}{1+j},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.

At the HealthPlus hospital, the nursing staff works in $6$ different shifts. Each shift has a duration of $8$ hours, with its start interval of $4$ hours (the first shift starts at $8:00$ AM, the second at $12:00$ AM, the third at $4:00$ p.m., and so on). The number of nurses required during the day is in the following table. How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning the nursing staff, considering that $x_{i}$ is the number of nurses working in shift $i~(i = 1~to~6)$?

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|}
\hline
\text{Day period} & \text{Required number of nurses} \\
\hline
\text{8:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m.} & 140 \\
\text{12:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.} & 120 \\
\text{4:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m.} & 160 \\
\text{8:00 p.m. to 12:00 p.m.} & 90 \\
\text{12:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m.} & 30 \\
\text{4:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.} & 60 \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]
answer2:
\[
		\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^5 x_{i}\\			
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\			
		& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
		&x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
		&x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
		&x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~5\\ 
		\end{array}
	     \]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
			\text{Maximize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+x_{2}\geq 120\\
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			& x_{i}\geq 0, i=1~to~6\\
			\end{array}
			\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll} 
				\text{Minimize} & Z= \sum_{i=1}^6 x_{i}\\			
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+x_{6}\geq 140\\			
			& x_{2}+x_{3}\geq 160\\			
			& x_{3}+x_{4}\geq 90\\			
			& x_{4}+x_{5}\geq 30\\			
			& x_{5}+x_{6}\geq 60\\
			\end{array}
			\]

(1+i)z& + & (1-i)w & = & i \\
(1-i)z& + & (1+i)w & = & 1-i
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The unique solution of the linear system is $\bigg(\frac{3+i}{4},-\frac{1+i}{4}\bigg)$.
answer2: The solutions of the linear system are of the form $\bigg(\frac{1+i}{4},\frac{-1+i}{4}+z\bigg)$, for every $z\in\mathbb{C}$.
answer3: The linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has the vector $(i,-i)$ has its unique solution.

Find the solutions of the following linear system, given the values of the parameters $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x &- &4y &- &4z &= &\alpha \\ 
x &- &3y &- &z &= &\beta \\ 
2x &+ &4y &+ &z &= &\gamma
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{-\alpha+12\beta+8\gamma}{29},\,\frac{3\alpha-7\beta+5\gamma}{29},\,\frac{-10\alpha+4\beta-7\gamma}{29}\right)$.
answer2: The system has no solution for $\alpha=\beta=\gamma=0$, and for all other choices of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma\mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution which is $\left(\alpha+3\beta-\gamma,\,\gamma,\,\beta-\gamma\right)$.
answer3: The sistem has no solutions for every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$.
answer4: For every choice of $\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in \mathbb{R}$, the system has infinite solutions, which are $\left(\alpha-\beta+\gamma+z,\,1+z,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
3x & - & y & - & 2z & = & a \\
-x & + & 3y & - & z & = & b \\
-2x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a \neq 1$ and $b \neq -1$.
If $a=1$ and $b=-1$, then the system has $\left(\frac{2+7z}{8},\,\frac{-2+5z}{8},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,1,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4:
The system has no solution if $a\neq 1$ and $b\neq 1$. 
If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(1+y,\,y,\,\frac{3+y}{4}\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the values of the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 3y & + & 6z & = & a \\ 
3x & + & y & + & 3z & = & 1 \\ 
6x & + & 6y & + & z & = & 1 \\
7x & + & 9y & + & 7z & = & b
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions for $b\neq a+1$. 

If $b=a+1$, then for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{37-14a}{100},\,\frac{3a-4}{20},\,\frac{1+3a}{25}\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer2: The system has no solution for every $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
If $b\neq a+1$, the system has no solutions. 

Otherwise, for every $a\in\mathbb{R}$ the system has $\left(\frac{3+3a-z}{2},\,\frac{2+a-2z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4:
If $b=a+1$ the system has no solution. 

Otherwise, for every $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$ the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(\frac{a+b+1}{20},\,\frac{-a-b+2}{3},\,\frac{2a+3b-4}{15}\right)$.

x &  &  & + & z & = & c
\end{cases}$$

$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & + & 2z & = & a \\
x & + & 2y & + & z & = & b \\
x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
4x & + & 3y & + & 4z & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has solutions if and only if $a=-2$ and $b=5$. 
In this case, there is an infinite number of solution, which are of the form $\left(x,\,4,\,-3-x\right)$ for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer2:
The system has solutions if and only if $a \neq \frac{7}{4}$ and $b \neq \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the solutions are of the form $\left(\frac{3}{4}a-z,\,\frac{1}{4}b,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has solutions if and only if $a = \frac{7}{4}$ and $b = \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the unique solution is $\left(\frac{3}{4},\,\frac{1}{4},\,0\right)$.

answer3:
$\begin{cases}
x(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+C_{2}e^{3t}(2\cos (t)-\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+2\sin (t))\\
y(t)=C_{2}e^{3t}(\cos (t)+3\sin (t))+C_{3}e^{3t}(3\cos (t)-\sin (t))\\
z(t)=C_{1}e^{2t}+2C_{2}e^{3t}\cos t+3C_{3}e^{3t}\sin t,
\end{cases}$

answer4:
$\begin{cases}

\end{cases}$

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & + & 2z & = & a \\
x & + & 2y & + & z & = & b \\
x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
4x & + & 3y & + & 4z & = & 0
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has solutions if and only if $a=-2$ and $b=5$. 
In this case, there is an infinite number of solution, which are of the form $\left(x,\,4,\,-3-x\right)$ for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer2:
The system has solutions if and only if $a \neq \frac{7}{4}$ and $b \neq \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the solutions are of the form $\left(\frac{3}{4}a-z,\,\frac{1}{4}b,\,z\right)$ for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
The system has solutions if and only if $a = \frac{7}{4}$ and $b = \frac{5}{4}$.
In this case, the unique solution is $\left(\frac{3}{4},\,\frac{1}{4},\,0\right)$.

The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:

The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:

Find the solution of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x_1 &- &x_2 &- &3x_3 &+ &4x_4 &= &1 \\
&x_1 &+ &x_2 &+ &x_3 &+ &2x_4 &= &-1 \\
& &- &x_2 &- &2x_3 &+ &x_4 &= &1 \\
&x_1 &+ &2x_2 &+ &3x_3 &+ &x_4 &= &-2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$(x_3-3x_4,-1-2x_3+x_4, x_3, x_4), \, \forall x_3,x_4\in\mathbb{R}$$
answer3:
The system has many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$(1-3x_4,-1+x_4, 1, x_4), \, \forall x_4\in\mathbb{R}$$.

question:
For each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, describe the solutions of the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1 \\
x & - & 2y & - & z & = & m \\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
For $m=-2$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m \neq -2$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer2: The linear system has no solution for every $m\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3:
For $m \in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has infinitely many solutions, which are of the form $\left(0,\,y,\,y-1\right)$ for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.
For $m=0$, the linear system has a unique solution, which is $\left(0,\,1,\,1\right)$.
For $m \not\in \{-2,\,0\}$, the linear system has no solutions.
answer4: The linear system has a unique solution for each $m\in\mathbb{R}$, which is $\left(0,\,m,\,m-1\right)$.

question: Find the domain and the image of the function $f(x,y,z) = \frac{x+y+z}{|x+y+z|}$.
answer1:
The domain of $f$ consists of all points $(x,y,z)$ in space but not on the plane $x+y+z=0$.
The image of $f$ is the set $\{-1,1\}$.
answer2:
The domain of $f$ consists of all points $(x,y,z)$ in space but not on the plane $x+y+z=0$.
The image of $f$ is the interval $[\,-1,1]$.
answer3:
The domain of $f$ consists of all points $(x,y,z)\in \mathbb{R}^{3}\setminus \{(0,0,0) \}$.
The image of $f$ is the interval $[\,-1,1]$.
answer4:
The domain of $f$ consists of all points $(x,y,z)\in \mathbb{R}^{3}\setminus \{(0,0,0) \}$.
The image of $f$ is the set $\{-1,1\}$.

question:
Find the solution of the following system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

question:
Anna and Josh decided to pick apples from a tree for 10 days.

Anna decided to pick 5 apples on the first day and every day that passed she would pick 3 more apples than the day before.

Josh decided to pick 3 apples on the first day and every day that passed he would pick 4 more apples than the day before.

Was there a day when Anna and Josh picked the same number of apples? If yes, what days were they?
answer4: They never picked the same number of apples.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
3x & - & y & - & 2z & = & a \\
-x & + & 3y & - & z & = & b \\
-2x & - & 2y & + & 3z & = & 0 \\
x & - & 3y & + & z & = & 1
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has no solutions if $a \neq 1$ and $b \neq -1$.
If $a=1$ and $b=-1$, then the system has $\left(\frac{2+7z}{8},\,\frac{-2+5z}{8},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,1,\,0\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4:
The system has no solution if $a\neq 1$ and $b\neq 1$. 
If $a=b=1$, the system has $\left(1+y,\,y,\,\frac{3+y}{4}\right)$ as solution for every $y\in\mathbb{R}$.

The WorldLight Company produces two light fixtures (products $1$ and $2$) that require both metal frame parts and electrical components. Management wants to determine how many units of each product to produce so as to maximize profit. For each unit of product $1$, $1$ unit of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. For each unit of product $2$, $3$ units of frame parts and $2$ units of electrical components are required. The company has $200$ units of frame parts and $300$ units of electrical components. 

Each unit of product $1$ gives a profit of $1?$, and each unit of product $2$, up to $60$ units, gives a profit of $2?$. Any excess over	$60$ units of product $2$ brings no profit, so such excess has been ruled out.

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning of the company's activity?
answer1:
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
		\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
	        & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			& x_{2}\leq 60\\
			&  x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer3:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Minimize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} & x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
			    & 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\leq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]
answer4:
\[\begin{array}{ll}
		\text{Maximize} & Z= x_{1} + 2x_{2}\\
			\text{subject to} &  x_{1}+3x_{2}\leq 200\\
    			& 2x_{1}+2x_{2}\leq 300\\
			    & x_{2}\geq 60\\
			    & x_{1},x_{2}\geq 0\\
\end{array}
\]

\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(\frac{1}{3}+\frac{5}{3}z,\,\frac{4}{3}+\frac{2}{3}z,\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has two solutions: $\left(1,\,0,\,-1\right)$ and $\left(0,\,2,\,-1\right)$.
